physDesc.p: This letter is 4 pages long (seq. 15-18). It is typed on something like notebook paper and words are printed on the page in a slanted manner. The words "John Gould " are written in pencil across the top of the first page. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I feel as though you had died, and I wonder where you are and what you are doing.

I send you Braithwaite’s article on us in "The New Republic," which I think is really very good, and also his review of your book, which is not so good; but still it has good space, and I think he meant it well. He says he is not satisfied with it, because he wrote it in a hurry, as he wanted to get it in; he felt no more time ought to elapse, and he was right there.

Ferris Greenslet tells me excellent things. He says that in a review in "Town and Country" about another book, they said that three things of importance had happened this year: the European war, "The New Republic," and Imagist poetry. And he tells me that the Anthology is selling about five copies a day.

Richard wrote me a cri du coeur and said that Miss Weaver had cut out his note on us for the June number. That was a shame; but he says you wrote him you did not want to be defended anyway, so you won’t be disappointed.
May Sinclair's article is very good. I am sending you an "Egoist."

I went in and saw Brown about "The Poetry Journal," and I think you are all right to send him something. I believe they mean to do well. He asked me for something, and I sent him an old poem of mine I do not care much about; but it is less modern than some things, and I do not believe he would take the very modern ones.

Ellery refused my polyphonic "Windmill," as I might have known he would; and I sent it off to William Rose Benet, who is on the editorial staff of "The Century." He wrote back a tremendously enthusiastic letter, and said he had recommended it for publication to the head editor; but, of course, I do not know whether said head editor will smile or not.
I wish you would send me a copy of the "Clipper Ships," and let me try "The New Republic" with it.
What has Greenslet done about your book? He told me that he thought it was too soon to bring it out at once, but he seemed to have distinct leanings toward keeping it and bringing it out later.

Did you go to Chicago, and did you see Harriet? She wrote Ferris a letter, pitching into us for not having mentioned her in the preface, and I have written her an answer, mentioning that she conducts a magazine, and that she was treated as all magazine editors always are; but I think we had better put in a paragraph in the preface of the 1916 Anthology, giving her a send-off.
We have put Mrs. Conkling into your place on the Executive Committee of the Poetry Club, and I really think that little society may be amusing in the end.

I have been slaving at my French poets, and they are now being typewritten. The translations I have not yet tackled. I have not written any poetry since you left, but I have got a couple of ideas which I shall tackle when I get settled in Dublin. I think I shall go up just about the Fourth.
Do write and tell me what you are doing and if you have written anything. After having seen you practically daily for four months, it seems awfully funny not to know anything about you.
